ownPages.title: com.javiersc.resource.extensions.resource
ownPages.content:
combine

Combine two Resource into one. Success happens when both are success Loading happens when one is Loading and the another is Loading or Success If there is only an error, defaultError will be used If both resources are error, error will be used or defaultError if it is null

combine

Combine two Resource into one. Both resources has the same error type. Success happens when both are success Loading happens when one is Loading and the another is Loading or Success If only one resource is error, it will be returned as error If both resources are errors, this will be returned as error

asFlow

Extension function to transform a Resource into a Flow.

folder

Extension function to fold a Resource. Check Resource.Folder inner class to see all the available options.

fold

Extension function to fold a Resource without builder.

ifLoading

Extension function with a callback which is invoked if Resource is Loading.

ifNoLoading

Extension function with a callback which is invoked if Resource is not Loading.

ifSuccess

Extension function with a callback which is invoked if Resource is Success and has data.

ifNoSuccess

Extension function with a callback which is invoked if Resource is not Success.

ifError

Extension function with a callback which is invoked if Resource is Error and has error data.

ifNoError

Extension function with a callback which is invoked if Resource is not Error.

map

Map any Resource to another Resource.

map

Map any Resource to another object, for example a ScreenState sealed class.

mapSuccess

Map any Resource to another Resource.

mapError

Map any Resource to another Resource.

ownPages.title: com.javiersc.resource.extensions
ownPages.content:
com.javiersc.resource.extensions.resource

asSuccess

Transform any thing to Success.

asSuccess

Transform any flow to a Success flow.

asError

Transform any thing to Error.

asError

Transform any flow to an Error flow.

asSuccessFlow

Transform any thing to Success Flow.

asErrorFlow

Transform any thing to Error.

map

Map a flow of resources to another object, for example a ScreenState sealed class

combine

Combine two Resource flows with the same error type into one

combineTransform

Combine and transform two Resource flows with the same error type into one

ownPages.title: Folder
ownPages.content:
A builder which lets fold a Resource with a series of functions that will be invoked based on the Resource state.

A builder which lets fold a Resource with a series of functions that will be invoked based on the Resource state.

loading noLoading success noSuccess error noError

ownPages.title: Success
ownPages.content:
Success state which has a param data of type S .

data

can be any object to be wrapped.

Success state which has a param data of type S .

ownPages.title: Error
ownPages.content:
Error state which has a param error of type E

error

can be any object to be wrapped.

Error state which has a param error of type E

This class lets wrap any thing and add an associated state: Loading, Success and Error.

Success happens when both are success Loading happens when one is Loading and the another is Loading or Success If only one resource is error, it will be returned as error If both resources are errors, this will be returned as error

ownPages.title: com.javiersc.resource
ownPages.content:
Resource

This class lets wrap any thing and add an associated state: Loading, Success and Error.

com.javiersc.resource.extensions

ownPages.title: Resource
ownPages.content:
Resource

Resource is a sealed class that allows you to wrap any object based on a state. It has these options:

  • üîÑ Loading: To use at that moment that a loading indicator should appear.
  • üëç Success: When the happy path occurs.
  • ‚ùå Error: If there is a problem you will get this.

This library works very well when used in conjunction with NetworkResponse which is very similar to Resource but is intended for use with Retrofit.

For more information see the website

Download

This library is Kotlin Multiplatform but at this moment jvm is the only artifact generated. It is available at Maven Central.

implementation("com.javiersc.resource:resource:$version")

Fold your Resource

Fold a Resource invokes multiple callbacks to manage its state for any event. A normal flow can be:

  1. Emit Loading to show the progress indicator.
  2. Emit Success to populate your data or emit Error if something were wrong to show an error.
val dog: Dog = Dog("Auri")
val resource: Resource<Dog, Error> = Resource.Success(dog)

resource.folder {
    loading { println("Loading: Yes") }
    noLoading { println("Loading: no") }  // Invoked

    success { dog: Dog -> println("Success: $dog") } // Invoked
    noSuccess { println("Success: no") }

    error { error: Error -> println("Error: $error") }
    noError { println("Error: no") }  // Invoked
}

Exists a fold function similar to folder buth without the builder pattern

val dog: Dog = Dog("Auri")
val resource: Resource<Dog, Error> = Resource.Success(dog)

resource.fold(
    loading = { println("Loading: Yes") },
    noLoading = { println("Loading: no") },  // Invoked
    success = { dog: Dog -> println("Success: $dog") }, // Invoked
    noSuccess = { println("Success: no") },
    error = { error: Error -> println("Error: $error") },
    noError = { println("Error: no") },  // Invoked
)

You don't have to add all those functions, for example, you usually only have to use:

  • loading to show a progress indicator.
  • noLoading to hide the progress indicator.
  • success to load the data.
  • error to show and error.

Mappers and common extension functions

Map a Resource to another Resource is possible with the following extension function:

  • Resource to Resource
val anotherResource: Resource<AnotherUser, AnotherError> = resource.map(
    success = { user: User -> user.toAnotherUser() },
    error = { error: Error -> error.toAnotherError() }
)
// toAnotherUser() and toAnotherError() mappers should be created by yourself, if they are
// extension functions and the resource uses inference for the type:
val anotherResource = resource.map(User::toAnotherUser, Error::toAnotherError)
  • Some value to Resource
val name: String = "Auri"
val nameResource = name.toResourceSuccess()

val message: String = "Some error message"
val messageResource = message.toResourceError()
  • A lot of checkers for each state, for example:
val resource: Resource<String> = Resource.Success("Auri")
resource.ifSuccess { data: String ->
    println(data) // "Auri"
}

You can see all the common extension functions here and here

Flow

There are four Flow extension functions:

  • Flow<R>.map(...) included in Kotlin, let you to easily map the object inside your Flow to any Resource:
val usersFlow: Flow<List<User>>

val usersResourceFlow: Flow<Resource<List<User>, Error>> =
    usersFlow.map { users: List<User> -> Resource.Success(users) }
  • Flow<R>.toResourceSuccess()
val usersSuccessFlow: Flow<Resource<List<User>, Error>> = usersFlow.toResourceSuccess()
  • Flow<R>.toResourceError()
val usersErrorFlow: Flow<Resource<List<User>, Error>> = usersFlow.toResourceError()

ownPages.title: Home
ownPages.content:
Resource

Resource is a sealed class that allows you to wrap any object based on a state. It has these options:

  • üîÑ Loading: To use at that moment that a loading indicator should appear.
  • üëç Success: When the happy path occurs.
  • ‚ùå Error: If there is a problem you will get this.

This library works very well when used in conjunction with NetworkResponse which is very similar to Resource but is intended for use with Retrofit.

Download

This library is Kotlin Multiplatform but at this moment jvm is the only artifact generated. It is available at Maven Central.

implementation("com.javiersc.resource:resource:$version")

Fold your Resource

Fold a Resource invokes multiple callbacks to manage its state for any event. A normal flow can be:

  1. Emit Loading to show the progress indicator.
  2. Emit Success to populate your data or emit Error if something were wrong to show an error.
val dog: Dog = Dog("Auri")
val resource: Resource<Dog, Error> = Resource.Success(dog)

resource.folder {
    loading { println("Loading: Yes") }
    noLoading { println("Loading: no") }  // Invoked

    success { dog: Dog -> println("Success: $dog") } // Invoked
    noSuccess { println("Success: no") }

    error { error: Error -> println("Error: $error") }
    noError { println("Error: no") }  // Invoked
}

Exists a fold function similar to folder buth without the builder pattern

val dog: Dog = Dog("Auri")
val resource: Resource<Dog, Error> = Resource.Success(dog)

resource.fold(
    loading = { println("Loading: Yes") },
    noLoading = { println("Loading: no") },  // Invoked
    success = { dog: Dog -> println("Success: $dog") }, // Invoked
    noSuccess = { println("Success: no") },
    error = { error: Error -> println("Error: $error") },
    noError = { println("Error: no") },  // Invoked
)

You don't have to add all those functions, for example, you usually only have to use:

  • loading to show a progress indicator.
  • noLoading to hide the progress indicator.
  • success to load the data.
  • error to show and error.

Mappers and common extension functions

Map a Resource to another Resource is possible with the following extension function:

  • Resource to Resource
val anotherResource: Resource<AnotherUser, AnotherError> = resource.map(
    success = { user: User -> user.toAnotherUser() },
    error = { error: Error -> error.toAnotherError() }
)
// toAnotherUser() and toAnotherError() mappers should be created by yourself, if they are
// extension functions and the resource uses inference for the type:
val anotherResource = resource.map(User::toAnotherUser, Error::toAnotherError)
  • Some value to Resource
val name: String = "Auri"
val nameResource = name.toResourceSuccess()

val message: String = "Some error message"
val messageResource = message.toResourceError()
  • A lot of checkers for each state, for example:
val resource: Resource<String> = Resource.Success("Auri")
resource.ifSuccess { data: String ->
    println(data) // "Auri"
}

You can see all the common extension functions here and here

Flow

There are four Flow extension functions:

  • Flow<R>.map(...) included in Kotlin, let you to easily map the object inside of your Flow to any Resource:
val usersFlow: Flow<List<User>>

val usersResourceFlow: Flow<Resource<List<User>, Error>> =
    usersFlow.map { users: List<User> -> Resource.Success(users) }
  • Flow<R>.toResourceSuccess()
val usersSuccessFlow: Flow<Resource<List<User>, Error>> = usersFlow.toResourceSuccess()
  • Flow<R>.toResourceError()
val usersErrorFlow: Flow<Resource<List<User>, Error>> = usersFlow.toResourceError()
